This occurred in one of jkarp's games against redfox17. And now, if black plays Nxe4 Nxe4 and d5! this gives black an open game with good development - but I think that after Nxe4 5. Bxf7+! Kxf7 6. Nxe4 is better.
He goes straight in for the kill.
The variation after exd5 is usually e4! and PXN PxN 8. cxb7 Bxb7 is better for black.
Now two pawns are lost via Nxe5.
Whoosh, no doubt threatening Qxe5.
Whoosh, no doubt threatening Qxe5.
[!] I actually overlooked Qxe5 here.
But, only just then ...
I realised I could pin the queen.
This doesn't help much, but loses a knight.
Still pinning and winning.
I actually prefer Qxe2, but this is quite the same.
Now I pin the bishop. I could only see two good moves, Nd7 or Ng4, but Ng4 fails to h3.

? I could see what Black was planning. After 12. Qxe5! Re8 13. Qf4 Re1+ 14. Bf1 and white is safe.
But anyhow, I hadn't realised this at the time, so I prepared to develop my bishop.
